intro: Syngonanthus hirtellus, commonly known as the hairy false heather, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes many shrubs and evergreens. The plant is characterized by its small, showy flowers that bloom in clusters, typically in shades of pink or white. Its leaves are narrow and covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. Syngonanthus hirtellus thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland habitats.
